Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Training Next Generation Faculty and Students to Address the Infrastructure Crisis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This TUES Type 2 project is establishing the Center for Infrastructure Transformation and Education (CIT-E) as the centerpiece of a community of practice. The aim is to facilitate the transformation of undergraduate civil and environmental engineering programs by incorporating infrastructure topics into their existing curriculum. This project builds upon the sophomore-level courses and other modules on civil infrastructure developed by the Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE) Department of the University of Wisconsin-Platteville and the Civil Engineering program at West Point Military Academy. The six collaborating institutions are of varying sizes, student population, and settings (Arizona State University, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, Norwich University, Portland State University, Rowan University, and University of Toledo). The project objectives are to: 1) establish and sustain the Center for Infrastructure Transformation and Education (CIT-E) as the source for infrastructure education materials that can be continuously improved by a community of practice, 2) develop educational expertise in infrastructure topics and in pedagogy in faculty at collaborating institutions, 3) deliver, assess, and institutionalize infrastructure-themed courses or modules for CEE and other majors at collaborating institutions, 4) enhance the ability of CEE students to view components and systems designed in CEE sub-disciplines as integral parts of the larger infrastructure system, and 5) enhance the ability of CEE students to view infrastructure challenges from a societal, rather than solely technical, perspective.

The project employs a creative model that engages collaborating faculty in roles of content creators and module maintainers of the infrastructure-themed course material to develop and sustain the community of practice. In addition, a structured plan to facilitate the adoption and institutionalization of infrastructure curricular material at the six collaborating institutions, and provide faculty development and support is used.

More than 500 students and fifteen faculty at eight diverse institutions, including some with large numbers of underrepresented minority students, are directly impacted by the project activities, increasing the number of students and faculty with knowledge and expertise in sustainable infrastructure topics. A community of practice centered on CIT-E and multiple faculty development workshops is employed to facilitate the dissemination and adoption of the curricular material and practices developed in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Exceptional progress has been made on this grant over the past four years, and all the original outcomes have been exceeded beyond the degree specified in the proposal.  For example, rather than simply share existing materials, the CIT-E (Center for Infrastructure Transformation and Education) community has created a model introductory infrastructure course complete with peer-reviewed lessons. The community has developed 43 lessons. These lessons have been collaboratively created by a group of experts; are current; use active learning exercises; are carefully designed such that pre-, in-, and post-class activities and assessments align with learning outcomes; and are engaging. The lessons have passed through internal and external peer review processes.

The community also held a total of four 3-day “Annual Infrastructure Education Workshops”, and the last one was held in Washington, D.C. on May 30 – June 2, 2017.  The last workshop was attended by 18 attendees from 16 different universities, companies, and organizations.  This fourth workshop begun the creation of 18 additional lessons for the model introductory infrastructure course, which are currently undergoing the peer-review process.  The workshops have succeeded in providing instructional design and course design expertise in the participants, and have provided opportunities to develop, modify and teach new courses at several institutions including Norwich University. The CIT-E.org website has ALSO been developed and is functional. 

At Norwich we have modified a “Site Development” course to become “Site Development and Infrastructure Engineering” and the course content was significantly modified to include infrastructure modules. Some of the modules for this course have been borrowed from the CIT-E website. Norwich University has also introduced infrastructure contents into two other courses, including Introduction to Transportation Engineering and Steel Design.      

The CIT-E community has grown extensively, and a database of participants includes 125 people (up from 83 one year ago) who are either actively involved; have expressed interest in being involved in the future; or have attended one of the CIT-E workshops. We have been able to progress much further in the four years than we had proposed that we would.  Where the original scope was to implement the course at five other universities, the course is now being implemented at more than 12 universities.    Moreover, where the initial scope was to share the materials developed at UW-Platteville and West Point with collaborators, we have gone beyond the sharing of existing content and have collaboratively created community-generated content for a model course.  The impact on the civil and environmental engineering education discipline is the creation of a community of practice that has collaboratively created the model introductory infrastructure courses. The community mentors new instructors with teaching and implementing their course and provides a way for members to share best practices and newly-discovered resources.
